element.name: Royal Canal Way-The Auld Triangle by Kili or bust, Multi-cache (1/1)

center.font: Visit The Geocaching Ireland discussion forum HERE

element.long-description:
"Oh a hungry feeling,
came o'er me stealing
And the mice they were squealing
in my prison cell
Then that auld triangle,
went jingle jangle
All along the banks of the Royal Canal!"
To begin the morning,
the screw was bawling
Get up you bowsie,
and clean up your cell
Then that auld triangle,
went jingle jangle
All along the banks of the Royal Canal
Oh the screw was peeping
and the lag lay sleeping
Dreamin` about his girl Sal
And that auld triangle,
went jingle jangle
All along the banks of the Royal Canal
In the female prison
there are seventy women
And among them I wish
I did dwell
And that auld triangle,
could go jingle jangle
All along the banks of the Royal Canal
The above coordinates should take you to see Dublin writer/playright Brendan Behan sitting with a feathered friend along the bank of the Royal Canal. To find the micro magnetic cache look at the plaque and find the date that the "Canal Watch was founded. In that date a figure appears twice. Use that as "A".
About 7/8 paces behind Brendan there is a pole with a number in black on yellow. Use this number as "BC".
The final coordinates are N53 21.6A6 W006 15.5(50+BC)
The towpath along the canal is now designated “The Royal Canal Way”. It is possible to walk from the 1st Dock in the centre of Dublin to the 40th lock and is being cleared further as restoration proceeds towards the Shannon and Longford. Signposts have been erected at each bridge between Clonsilla and Mullingar. Eventually these will be extended to cover the entire length of the canal.
Behan, the writer
Behan's prison experiences were central to his future writing career. In Mountjoy he wrote his first play, The Landlady and also began to write short stories and other prose. Some of this work was published in The Bell, the leading Irish literary magazine of the time. He also learned Irish in prison and after his release in 1946, he spent some time in the Gaeltacht areas of Galway and Kerry, where he started writing poetry in Irish. By the early 1950s he was earning a living as a writer for radio and newspapers and had gained a reputation as something of a character on the streets and in literary circles in Dublin.
His major breakthrough came in 1954 when his play The Quare Fellow, which was based on his experiences in jail, was produced in the Pike Theatre in Dublin. The play ran for six months. In May 1956, The Quare Fellow opened in the Theatre Royal, Stratford, in a production by Joan Littlewood, bringing international fame to the author.
In 1957, his Irish language play, An Giall (The Hostage) opened in the Damer Theatre, and his autobiographical novel Borstal Boy was published. Behan was now established as one of the leading Irish writers of his generation.
Behan was perhaps the most famous Irish writer of his time, and was once hired to write an advertising slogan for Guinness. As part of his payment for this, the company offered him half a dozen kegs of their stout. After a month the company asked Behan what he had come up with; Behan had already managed to drink all of the beer they had given him and produced the slogan Guinness Makes You Drunk. Erroneously, he is also sometimes credited with "Guinness is Good for You", which was actually written by Dorothy L. Sayers. The Royal Canal This cache is part of a series placed along the Royal Canal Way. The series follows the towpaths along the Royal Canal heading westwards towards the Shannon River. There are a number of caches in the Dublin region stretching from the city centre out into the country. Except for the first two centre city caches all of these, and any clues or hints take you in the direction against the water flow. To get the full benefit of this series I would suggest that it is best done on foot or on a bicycle though most of the caches may also be accessed by car. I have to say that the car option will take considerable time, petrol and nausea inducing traffic frustration not to mention considerable difficulty with parking. During winter or wet conditions hiking boots or good waterproof shoes will be required as the canal towpath can become very sloppy and almost impossible in one or two spots. ""BE AWARE OF THE DANGER AND THE SLIPPY MUD CLOSE TO THE WATER AT ALL TIMES PLEASE"" There area number of Sidetrack caches at the railway stations along the canal walk. A small detour at these points will bring you to each one.

ul.li:
2010-06-03T19:00:00Z : Found it by eve1987
With another small hint from the owner the 2nd time it worked ;)
TFTC

2010-06-03T19:00:00Z : Found it by GudrunXY
Found with eve1987 on our caching tour through Ireland. At the second attempt with help from the owner we found it quite fast. TFTC GudrunXY

2010-03-28T19:00:00Z : Found it by Lahtac
Nice easy find. TFTC SL

2010-03-28T19:00:00Z : Found it by OBCLAN
2nd find of the day. Was on a roll by now. TFTC SL

2010-03-09T20:00:00Z : Found it by kaquirk
While our Irish friends did some maintenance on the database, we treated ourselves to an afternoon walk in the sun. Many muggles around, but with a little help from my friends, this could be logged without to much trouble. This was a very nice place and a very nice day. We love the sculpture. TFTC!

2009-03-17T19:00:00Z : Found it by Kersti.com
A gorgeous St Paddy's Day saw Christian and I out for a bike ride along the Royal Canal. We stopped to pick up this cache, which was an easy find although a rather difficult return thanks to all the parade-going muggles walking past. TFTC
